awd_titl_txt: Preparing and Supporting Equitable Teaching in Mathematics and Science Classrooms: The FSU-Teach Noyce Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Through funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Program, this Noyce Scholarship Track Phase II project will address the established and growing national need to improve quantity and increase quality of the teaching workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). With the understanding that there is a significant opportunity gap for students from high needs schools compared to students from more affluent schools, Florida State University (FSU) will work closely with partner insitutions, (which include five high needs school districts, Tallahassee Community College, and the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory), to address and help close this gap. In particular, the Project Team from FSU will build on lessons learned from its Phase I project and collaborate with its internal partners and partner institutions to support new teachers and attract, prepare, and support future teachers to have the background and resources to teach well, specifically with a focus on effective and reformed science and mathematics teaching in high needs middle and high school settings. The project will support a total of one hundred ten (110) potential new teachers through internships or scholarships. To foster networking and deeper understanding of needs, the multidisciplinary community associated with this project (including STEM and education faculty, interns, graduates, mentors, and teachers) will meet annually in a STEM Equity Conference. A focus of this conference will be on the various issues related to STEM instruction in high needs settings. 

For recruitment, the program will offer seventy-five (75)internships through which STEM majors will explore teaching through participating in outreach that, under the guidance of a STEM faculty, will engage K-12 students from high needs settings. A comprehensive teacher preparation program will be provided for the thirty-five (35) undergraduate Noyce scholars pursuing STEM teaching. These scholars will be involved in an ongoing series of activities under the guidance of partner mentors; they will learn to navigate the difficulties associated with engaging high needs students in ambitious instruction that will be rich in STEM practices and guided by research. For support after these students graduate and receive a teaching position in a high needs school, face-to-face and virtual activities will be provided to assist them in understanding their school sites, accessing necessary resources, and honing their instruction to be both challenging and effective for their students. In addition to providing opportunities, content and pedagogical education, and support for Noyce interns and scholars, this Phase II project will feature research designed to identify and explore: (i) the dispositions and beliefs that position pre-service and novice teachers for success in delivering ambitious STEM instruction; (ii) the program supports needed to assist those novice teachers; and (iii) the school contexts that best support novices in their first years of work. Using qualitative comparative analysis (QCA) as the analytical approach, investigators will analyze data from surveys, interviews, and classroom observations to move toward quantification of possible relationships between effect, belief, and practice. In turn, this research will allow results from the project to inform the efforts of others involved in the recruitment, preparation, and support of novice STEM teachers.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative partnership between the department of Biology, Mathematics, Engineering and the School of Teacher Education, this project included the following outcomes: The development and implementation of a STEM Outreach for At-Risk Youth (SOAR) internships program, connecting 65 STEM students with faculty engaged in outreach with students from high needs settings in the practices of the discipline; The development and implementation of a NOYCE selection process and professional development program that focused on ambitious STEM instruction engages students in sensemaking in mathematics and science, resulting 38 Noyce scholars working in high needs schools after graduation; The development and implementation of a new teacher support program to focused on the need for and barriers to ambitious STEM instruction, this program allowed graduates to become more effective in their classroom setting; Research that illuminates the intersection of rigorous instruction and culturally relevant instruction in STEM. 

Intellectual Merit.  The project has led to the development and dissemination of new educational materials in the form of a course syllabus targeting Equity in STEM to be shared at a national organization of STEM education programs (UTeach) and lead to ideas for new pedagogical methods, in the form of the categorization system designed for types of relevance, something that will allow for more targeted development of relevance in lesson planning by preservice and inservice teachers. Both the course syllabus and the categorization system for types of relevance in STEM?as well as one doctoral dissertation and a number of regional and national presentations and workshops emerged from this research.  The research conducted involved the conceptualization of the relationship of rigor (thought of as the cognitive demand of the tasks assigned to students) and relevance (thought of as the importance the material targeted has for students? and their motivation to engage with it) in STEM teaching.  The results have particular salience for teaching. The categorization system for relevance allows novice teachers to distinguish between constructed relevance (i.e. relevance that does not consider knowledge emerging from students? cultural lives) and relevance that draws on students? cultural knowledge. The implications of this work suggest that introducing novice teachers to different types of relevance and the affordances of each type of relevance could prove beneficial for furthering the use of relevance in lessons, thus enhancing the effectiveness of STEM instruction for students traditionally underserved in STEM courses.  Findings from research emerging from this project as well as anecdotal findings from the Noyce scholar seminar series points to the need for a much stronger emphasis on teachers (preservice and inservice) to better understand and build relationships with the students they teach.

Broader Impact.  Mentoring supported and/or informed by this project included mentoring of graduate students in terms of research--including research design, analysis, presentation and publication (three graduate students), and management of outreach programs targeting underserved students), and course design around issues of equity in STEM (mentoring of one graduate student and one post doctoral scholar). Teaching supported and/or informed by this project included over 65 outreach efforts in high needs settings, monthly seminars targeting the Noyce scholars, workshops focused on equity in STEM open to scholars, graduates and members of the local communities, Noyce scholars student teaching experiences and their first years of practice as novice teachers, and the design of a new course focused on equity in STEM now required in the teacher education program that housed the Noyce program. The techniques to support the development of preservice teachers? attention to and strategies for cultural relevance developed in this project as well as the support for recruiting and supporting novice STEM teachers working in High-Needs schools will allow teachers to engage learners traditionally underserved in STEM more effectively.  As these students develop, this effort has promise in improving the STEM knowledge, attitudes, skills, and abilities of individuals served by those teachers.  This will have both economic consequences for those learners, as well as implications for developing a citizenry that is willing to engage in consideration of STEM for personal and social decision making.

Modified by: Sherry A Southerland

The project has led to the development and dissemination of new educational materials in the form of a course syllabus targeting Equity in STEM to be shared at a national organization of STEM education programs (UTeach) and lead to ideas for new pedagogical methods, in the form of the categorization system designed for types of relevance, something that will allow for more targeted development of relevance in lesson planning by preservice and inservice teachers. Both the course syllabus and the categorization system for types of relevance in STEM?as well as one doctoral dissertation and a number of regional and national presentations and workshops emerged from this research. Mentoring supported and/or informed by this project included mentoring of graduate students in terms of research--including research design, analysis, presentation and publication (three graduate students), and management of outreach programs targeting underserved students), and course design around issues of equity in STEM (mentoring of one graduate student and one post doctoral scholar). As these students develop, this effort has promise in improving the STEM knowledge, attitudes, skills, and abilities of individuals served by those teachers.  This will have both economic consequences for those learners, as well as implications for developing a citizenry that is willing to engage in consideration of STEM for personal and social decision making.
